TRACK MEN STAR AT PENN RELAYS
Clarke Gets First and Second in
Dashes. Booth Wins
Two Mile
America was victorious in the
first international event on the
program when Louis Clarke of
Johns Hopkins University won
the 220-yard dash at the Penn Relays last Friday. The great. ScotT
tish runner, Eric Liddell of Edinburgh University, set the pace
until the last twenty yards when
Clarke passed him to win the race
in 21 3-5 seconds.
The following Day_ Clarke ran
second to Bowman, of Syracuse,
in the century. Liddell was beaten
for third place by Conway, of
Penn State.
Booth, Johns Hopkins star,
brought more glory to Homewood
when he captured the two mile
international run, breasting the
tape ahead of Lermond, the Boston College flash. Phelps, of
Iowa, was third, and Helme, of
Georgetown, fourth. The Black
and Blue took fourth place in the
quarter mile championship relay,
which was won by Columbia.
The relay team representing
BoSton College set up a new
world's record when the combination went the distance in the remarkable time of 7 minutes 47 3-5
seconds.

BRILLIANT WEEK-END
FOR BLACK AND
BLUE
Meeting opponents of high
caliber, Hopkins went
through the past week-end
with a clean slate. Navy was
defeated at lacrosse; Clarke
and Booth added to their
string of victories by beating
out a picked field in their respecitve events at Penn; and
the baseball team won over
Dickinson.
After a month of spring
sports, Hopkins has not been
defeated in lacrosse or track,
and has had an.even break in
baseball.

GRADUATES MOURN DEATH
OF FIRST HOPKINS
PSYCHOLOGIST

BLUE JAYS WIN HISTORY-MAKING
GAME AFTER TRAILING FIRST HALF

Dr. Stanley Hall Dies in New England, Turnbull Leads Successful Attack and Benedict Scores Winning Goal.
Leaving Record of Achievements
Team Shows Speed and Fighting Spirit
in Field of Psychology

Hopkins graduate circles received a shock when news was received of the death of Dr. G. Stanley Hall, first professor of psychology at this university. Many are
mourning the death of, the pioneer
psychologist who died last Thursday, April 24, at his home in New
England. Hopkins men who studied under Dr. Hall during the
seven years of his Hopkins professorship dating from 1881 to
1888 feel the great extent of the
world's loss.
Dr. Dunlap, head of the Psychology Department at Johns Hopkins,
eulogized the deceased professor.
"He was," said Dr. Dunlap, "a
most stimulating teacher. Heads of
psychology departments in colleges
all over the country owe their original interest in the subject to inspiration received from him. Hopkins graduates in particular have a
lively remembrance of his courses."
Dr. Hall was born on February
1, 1846, He received his A. B. degree from Williams in 1867. His
subsequent studies were extensive.
He studied at Union Theological
Seminary and received his Ph. D.
from Heidelburg. Later he was
the recipient of other degrees at
Harvard, Hopkins and other universities. In 1881 he came to Hopkins to become head of the newly
organized department of psychology, which position he held until
1888, when he became President of
Clark University, which had just
been founded. His successful administration there lasted until 1920,
when he retired with the title of
President Emeritus, which he held
until his death.
Dr. Hall was an undisputed leader in American psychology. While
at Hopkins he founded the first
psychological laboratory in the
United States. In 1892 he organized and became president of the
American Psychological Association, and in 1897 he helped found
the American Journal of Psychology. Shortly before his death Dr.
Hall was again elected president of
the American Psychological Association as a tribute for his wonderful research work.
Many books, ten of which are
psychology texts, were written by
Dr. Hall. In his "Confessions of a
Psychologist" he tells how he advised Woodrow Wilson to abandon
psychology for political science.

SIGMA UPSILON TO INITIATE
FIVE MEN
At six o'clock this evening the
Hopkins Club will be the scene of
the spring initiation of the Purple
Gown Chapter of the Sigma Upsilon National Literary Fraternity.
The initiates are: Mr. John Earle
Uhler, Alger Hiss, George Weinfeld, William Calhoun and Pendleton Herring. All except Mr. Uhler
were elected to active membership
in the society; Mr. Uhler, who is an
instructor in English, was elected
to associate membership.
Following the initiation a banquet will be held after which officers for the coming year will be
elected.

TENNIS TEAM FACES HARD
SCHEDULE; MEETS MARYLAND MAY 3
On account of bad weather the
first scheduled match for the tennis
team had to be called off. It was
to have been played April 19 with
the Eastern Country Club. There
is a match pending with Georgetown on May 1, at Washington.
The prospects for winning are
bright, the teams having put in
about two weeks of stiff practice.
The team has been picked and is
composed of Hofmeister, captain;
Berlinghof, Sturman and Hebner.
In the doubles, Hofmeister is
paired with Hebner for first and
Berlinghof with Stulman for second. The schedule is as follows:
May 1, Georgetown, Washington
(pending); May 3, Maryland, College Park; May 10, Baltimore
Country Club, Roland Park; May
21, Navy, Annapolis; May 24, University of Delaware, Home; June
7, University of Virginia, Home.
There is a return match pending

with Maryland for May 17 here.
The match with the University of
Virginia •is to take place in the
midst of the June Week activities.
The team 'has high hopes of trouncing Maryland and even chances
of beating Navy.
NINE STUDENTS ELECTED TO
PI DELTA EPSILON
At the atinual election of the
Johns Hopkins Chapter of the Pi
Delta Epsilon, the National Journalist Fraternity, the following men
were voted into membership: Hutzler, Hamburger, Hiss, Keller,
stick, Griffiths, Wales, Young and
Metcalf.
The chapter will hold a banquet
next Thursday. Many prominent
alumni residing in the city will be
present.
The fraternity is a very large
national organization and its membership includes some of the most
prominent men in the world of
journalism. The late President
Harding was a member.

HOIVIEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1924

1500 awarded

to prize
winners from 60 different
colleges

VICTORY!
Johns Hopkins has every reason to be proud of her athletic
teams, for during the past week-end the Black and Blue squads disdistinguished themselves in every branch of sport. Booth and Clarke
ran away with track honors at the Penn Relay Carnival; the baseball
team defeated Dickinson; the lacrosse team scored a signal victory
over the Naval Academy. The Navy defeat, the first suffered from
the hands of a Hopkins team for seven years, was of such a nature
as to thrill the large crowd that thronged the stands. In addition to
this the undergraduate body made a splendid showing at the Navy
game. Our teams are to be congratulated for their excellent work;
the student body is to be congratulated for its loyal support.
One thing, however, stands in the way of a perfect spring sport
season. This is the lacrosse team of the University of Maryland.
Let us, then, adopt the slogan "plow up Maryland."
THINK THIS OVER
Only the warm rays of Spring's sunlight were needed to loose
the political bee that has been buzzing under cover for many months.
Noise from that little bee is heard as one by one the campus positions
are surrendered from senior hands to underclassmen. Elections to
the Athletic Board and the Student Council, by far the most important positions on the campus, are scheduled to be held within a few
weeks. It may seem early to get down to definite decisions, yet it
does not mean that the Student Body should not start at once to
think about the business to be conducted within a short time. Rather
does it mean that there is all too little time left for thorough consideration and sincere deliberation of the affair of electing officers to responsible posts.
As far as records of human activity extend, evidences of conspiracies are found whereby "politicians" were aided in securing
power. Descendants of noted political tribes seem to have come
upon the campus of many colleges. In fact, a college campus is
often characterized as being controlled by this or that faction. It is
regrettable, yet logical, that fraternities should be made the seat of
such political factions. At some colleges it is known that many
students automatically support a candidate merely because he happens to be a member of their fraternity, or of their "allied" fraternity.
The men in the ranks of the so-called opposition are never considered,
even though they possess merits which deserve the closest attention.
Then there are some who do not worry their heads about candidates;
they cast a ballot, usually,accepting the advice of some kind-hearted
friend.
It is interesting to note what a prominent college paper has to say
regarding student voting and to apply their thought to Hopkins, unfortunately in the swirl of political activity. In the McGill Daily
we read—"Vote, but above all things, vote intelligently. There really
should be no need whatever to urge intelligent action among university students. But even the best regulated humans are liable to permit their biased enthusiasm to cover up and smother their reason;
and even the most precise and business-like may lapse, because of
the weakness of nature, into a period of haphazard action."
We wish to repeat—"Vote, but above all things, vote intelligently."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 29. 1924

THREE PLAYLETS
PRESENTED BY

Uhe Playshoppers
As the final offering
of the season the Homewood Playshop presented
last Thursday, Friday
and Saturday evenings a
•'satirical fantasy," a romantic playlet and a
slightly modified scene
from Henry VIII. of the three,
the modern fantasy was much the
least satisfying. For a relatively
unknown author, it is rather an acid
test to be on the same program
with Shakespeare and Rostand.
'The Six Stokers Who Owned
the Bloomin' Earth," by E. L.
Greenefelder, a Hopkins alumnus.
was the curtain raiser for this last
productioni—a curtain raiser that
was a full thirty minutes late. Except for John Earle Uhler, the male
members of the cast were unable
to shake off a strained unnaturalness that presented the illusion so
necessary in symbolic drama. The
grouping at the curtain and the
ironic note throughout Were, however, most effective.
The one act version of Edward
Rostand's "Les Romanesques," was
in general charmingly interpreted,
although the miscasting of Arnold
Frank as Pasquinot destroyed much
of the atmosphere so well achieved
by the other characters. The gentle,
romantic, fantastic, slightly mocking tone of Rostand's was delicately brought out.
Scene II. from the third act of
"Henry VIII." was the most pretentious attempt of the trio, and, on
the whole, the most successful. The
acting of Stanley Worden as Wolsey rang true at all times, and although Norman Bean, as Surrey,
bore a much closer physical resemblance to the reproductions of
Henry than did Bromley Smith, the
four actors seemed perfectly at
home in their roles.
It is interesting to note the much
more finished performance of Gerald B. Bryan as the Cromwell of
Shakespeare than the same actor's
interpretation of Etcetero in the
first playlet of the production. All
amateurishness vanished when the
part was really large enough, definite enough to be grasped by the
actor.
The presence of several undergraduates in the cast and of more
than the usual quota in the audience was especially noticeable.
The music was an integral part
of the presentation and up to its
usual standard. Of the mechanical equipment, only the lighting appeared cramped, but nevertheless
remarkable in so small a theater.

PHYSICS STUDENTS SAIL
FOR GERMANY
Mr. Benard Kurrelmeyer and
Mr. Fritz Douman, both students
of physics at Johns Hopkins, sailed
Saturday for Germany, where they
will pursue a summer course in
physics at the University of Gottingen. Next year they will probably study at Munich.
Mr. Kurrelmeyer took his oral
examination for his Ph. D. degree
last Friday. He is the son of Dr.
William Kurrelmeyer, Associate
Professor of German at Hopkins.

TRACK MEN STAR AT PENN RELAYS
Clarke Gets First and Second in
Dashes. Booth Wins
Two Mile
America was victorious in the
first international event on the
program when Louis Clarke of
Johns Hopkins University won
the 220-yard dash at the Penn Relays last Friday. The great. ScotT
tish runner, Eric Liddell of Edinburgh University, set the pace
until the last twenty yards when
Clarke passed him to win the race
in 21 3-5 seconds.
The following Day_ Clarke ran
second to Bowman, of Syracuse,
in the century. Liddell was beaten
for third place by Conway, of
Penn State.
Booth, Johns Hopkins star,
brought more glory to Homewood
when he captured the two mile
international run, breasting the
tape ahead of Lermond, the Boston College flash. Phelps, of
Iowa, was third, and Helme, of
Georgetown, fourth. The Black
and Blue took fourth place in the
quarter mile championship relay,
which was won by Columbia.
The relay team representing
BoSton College set up a new
world's record when the combination went the distance in the remarkable time of 7 minutes 47 3-5
seconds.

BRILLIANT WEEK-END
FOR BLACK AND
BLUE
Meeting opponents of high
caliber, Hopkins went
through the past week-end
with a clean slate. Navy was
defeated at lacrosse; Clarke
and Booth added to their
string of victories by beating
out a picked field in their respecitve events at Penn; and
the baseball team won over
Dickinson.
After a month of spring
sports, Hopkins has not been
defeated in lacrosse or track,
and has had an.even break in
baseball.

GRADUATES MOURN DEATH
OF FIRST HOPKINS
PSYCHOLOGIST

BLUE JAYS WIN HISTORY-MAKING
GAME AFTER TRAILING FIRST HALF

Dr. Stanley Hall Dies in New England, Turnbull Leads Successful Attack and Benedict Scores Winning Goal.
Leaving Record of Achievements
Team Shows Speed and Fighting Spirit
in Field of Psychology

Hopkins graduate circles received a shock when news was received of the death of Dr. G. Stanley Hall, first professor of psychology at this university. Many are
mourning the death of, the pioneer
psychologist who died last Thursday, April 24, at his home in New
England. Hopkins men who studied under Dr. Hall during the
seven years of his Hopkins professorship dating from 1881 to
1888 feel the great extent of the
world's loss.
Dr. Dunlap, head of the Psychology Department at Johns Hopkins,
eulogized the deceased professor.
"He was," said Dr. Dunlap, "a
most stimulating teacher. Heads of
psychology departments in colleges
all over the country owe their original interest in the subject to inspiration received from him. Hopkins graduates in particular have a
lively remembrance of his courses."
Dr. Hall was born on February
1, 1846, He received his A. B. degree from Williams in 1867. His
subsequent studies were extensive.
He studied at Union Theological
Seminary and received his Ph. D.
from Heidelburg. Later he was
the recipient of other degrees at
Harvard, Hopkins and other universities. In 1881 he came to Hopkins to become head of the newly
organized department of psychology, which position he held until
1888, when he became President of
Clark University, which had just
been founded. His successful administration there lasted until 1920,
when he retired with the title of
President Emeritus, which he held
until his death.
Dr. Hall was an undisputed leader in American psychology. While
at Hopkins he founded the first
psychological laboratory in the
United States. In 1892 he organized and became president of the
American Psychological Association, and in 1897 he helped found
the American Journal of Psychology. Shortly before his death Dr.
Hall was again elected president of
the American Psychological Association as a tribute for his wonderful research work.
Many books, ten of which are
psychology texts, were written by
Dr. Hall. In his "Confessions of a
Psychologist" he tells how he advised Woodrow Wilson to abandon
psychology for political science.

SIGMA UPSILON TO INITIATE
FIVE MEN
At six o'clock this evening the
Hopkins Club will be the scene of
the spring initiation of the Purple
Gown Chapter of the Sigma Upsilon National Literary Fraternity.
The initiates are: Mr. John Earle
Uhler, Alger Hiss, George Weinfeld, William Calhoun and Pendleton Herring. All except Mr. Uhler
were elected to active membership
in the society; Mr. Uhler, who is an
instructor in English, was elected
to associate membership.
Following the initiation a banquet will be held after which officers for the coming year will be
elected.

TENNIS TEAM FACES HARD
SCHEDULE; MEETS MARYLAND MAY 3
On account of bad weather the
first scheduled match for the tennis
team had to be called off. It was
to have been played April 19 with
the Eastern Country Club. There
is a match pending with Georgetown on May 1, at Washington.
The prospects for winning are
bright, the teams having put in
about two weeks of stiff practice.
The team has been picked and is
composed of Hofmeister, captain;
Berlinghof, Sturman and Hebner.
In the doubles, Hofmeister is
paired with Hebner for first and
Berlinghof with Stulman for second. The schedule is as follows:
May 1, Georgetown, Washington
(pending); May 3, Maryland, College Park; May 10, Baltimore
Country Club, Roland Park; May
21, Navy, Annapolis; May 24, University of Delaware, Home; June
7, University of Virginia, Home.
There is a return match pending

with Maryland for May 17 here.
The match with the University of
Virginia •is to take place in the
midst of the June Week activities.
The team 'has high hopes of trouncing Maryland and even chances
of beating Navy.
NINE STUDENTS ELECTED TO
PI DELTA EPSILON
At the atinual election of the
Johns Hopkins Chapter of the Pi
Delta Epsilon, the National Journalist Fraternity, the following men
were voted into membership: Hutzler, Hamburger, Hiss, Keller,
stick, Griffiths, Wales, Young and
Metcalf.
The chapter will hold a banquet
next Thursday. Many prominent
alumni residing in the city will be
present.
The fraternity is a very large
national organization and its membership includes some of the most
prominent men in the world of
journalism. The late President
Harding was a member.

VICTORY!
Johns Hopkins has every reason to be proud of her athletic
teams, for during the past week-end the Black and Blue squads disdistinguished themselves in every branch of sport. Booth and Clarke
ran away with track honors at the Penn Relay Carnival; the baseball
team defeated Dickinson; the lacrosse team scored a signal victory
over the Naval Academy. The Navy defeat, the first suffered from
the hands of a Hopkins team for seven years, was of such a nature
as to thrill the large crowd that thronged the stands. In addition to
this the undergraduate body made a splendid showing at the Navy
game. Our teams are to be congratulated for their excellent work;
the student body is to be congratulated for its loyal support.
One thing, however, stands in the way of a perfect spring sport
season. This is the lacrosse team of the University of Maryland.
Let us, then, adopt the slogan "plow up Maryland."
THINK THIS OVER
Only the warm rays of Spring's sunlight were needed to loose
the political bee that has been buzzing under cover for many months.
Noise from that little bee is heard as one by one the campus positions
are surrendered from senior hands to underclassmen. Elections to
the Athletic Board and the Student Council, by far the most important positions on the campus, are scheduled to be held within a few
weeks. It may seem early to get down to definite decisions, yet it
does not mean that the Student Body should not start at once to
think about the business to be conducted within a short time. Rather
does it mean that there is all too little time left for thorough consideration and sincere deliberation of the affair of electing officers to responsible posts.
As far as records of human activity extend, evidences of conspiracies are found whereby "politicians" were aided in securing
power. Descendants of noted political tribes seem to have come
upon the campus of many colleges. In fact, a college campus is
often characterized as being controlled by this or that faction. It is
regrettable, yet logical, that fraternities should be made the seat of
such political factions. At some colleges it is known that many
students automatically support a candidate merely because he happens to be a member of their fraternity, or of their "allied" fraternity.
The men in the ranks of the so-called opposition are never considered,
even though they possess merits which deserve the closest attention.
Then there are some who do not worry their heads about candidates;
they cast a ballot, usually,accepting the advice of some kind-hearted
friend.
It is interesting to note what a prominent college paper has to say
regarding student voting and to apply their thought to Hopkins, unfortunately in the swirl of political activity. In the McGill Daily
we read—"Vote, but above all things, vote intelligently. There really
should be no need whatever to urge intelligent action among university students. But even the best regulated humans are liable to permit their biased enthusiasm to cover up and smother their reason;
and even the most precise and business-like may lapse, because of
the weakness of nature, into a period of haphazard action."
We wish to repeat—"Vote, but above all things, vote intelligently."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 29. 1924

THREE PLAYLETS
PRESENTED BY

Uhe Playshoppers
As the final offering
of the season the Homewood Playshop presented
last Thursday, Friday
and Saturday evenings a
•'satirical fantasy," a romantic playlet and a
slightly modified scene
from Henry VIII. of the three,
the modern fantasy was much the
least satisfying. For a relatively
unknown author, it is rather an acid
test to be on the same program
with Shakespeare and Rostand.
'The Six Stokers Who Owned
the Bloomin' Earth," by E. L.
Greenefelder, a Hopkins alumnus.
was the curtain raiser for this last
productioni—a curtain raiser that
was a full thirty minutes late. Except for John Earle Uhler, the male
members of the cast were unable
to shake off a strained unnaturalness that presented the illusion so
necessary in symbolic drama. The
grouping at the curtain and the
ironic note throughout Were, however, most effective.
The one act version of Edward
Rostand's "Les Romanesques," was
in general charmingly interpreted,
although the miscasting of Arnold
Frank as Pasquinot destroyed much
of the atmosphere so well achieved
by the other characters. The gentle,
romantic, fantastic, slightly mocking tone of Rostand's was delicately brought out.
Scene II. from the third act of
"Henry VIII." was the most pretentious attempt of the trio, and, on
the whole, the most successful. The
acting of Stanley Worden as Wolsey rang true at all times, and although Norman Bean, as Surrey,
bore a much closer physical resemblance to the reproductions of
Henry than did Bromley Smith, the
four actors seemed perfectly at
home in their roles.
It is interesting to note the much
more finished performance of Gerald B. Bryan as the Cromwell of
Shakespeare than the same actor's
interpretation of Etcetero in the
first playlet of the production. All
amateurishness vanished when the
part was really large enough, definite enough to be grasped by the
actor.
The presence of several undergraduates in the cast and of more
than the usual quota in the audience was especially noticeable.
The music was an integral part
of the presentation and up to its
usual standard. Of the mechanical equipment, only the lighting appeared cramped, but nevertheless
remarkable in so small a theater.
Shorty—"Ah tell you, nigger,
George wuz the honestest man
dat ever wuz born."
Long Boy—"Den, how come
dey closes de banks on his birfday?"—Georgia Cracker.

A large number of the faculty
will attend the convention of the
National Academy of Science to be
held Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of this week at Washington.
A great deal of interest has been
aroused among the professors.
The entire Physic's Faculty attended the meeting of dr Maryland Physical Society last Friday
and Saturday. At the banquet Professor Henry Crew delivered an address. He took the degree of Ph
D. at Johns Hopkins and his son,
William Crew, is an undergraduate
student now.

PHYSICS STUDENTS SAIL
FOR GERMANY
Mr. Benard Kurrelmeyer and
Mr. Fritz Douman, both students
of physics at Johns Hopkins, sailed
Saturday for Germany, where they
will pursue a summer course in
physics at the University of Gottingen. Next year they will probably study at Munich.
Mr. Kurrelmeyer took his oral
examination for his Ph. D. degree
last Friday. He is the son of Dr.
William Kurrelmeyer, Associate
Professor of German at Hopkins.
